subject: Re: [junit] a test framework to codify levelizaton?
msgSnippet: ... That s wonderful.  But it s impossible and likely incorrect to compare those results to any other project in any way other than a purely statistical
messageBody:
On Jul 17, 2004, at 9:55 AM, Jason Rogers wrote:

>
> On Sat, 17 Jul 2004 00:03:03 -0400, "J. B. Rainsberger"
> <jbrains@...> said:
>>
>> Vlad Roubtsov wrote:
>>> On any but the trivial projects the number of
>>> testcases quickly exceeds 100-200+. It usually takes a
>>> noticeable time to run them all.
>> Can you quantify this? GSBase, for example, runs tests at
>> approximately
>> 100/second, and that's my usual performance goal for tests. On
>> my most
>> recent project, I separated tests that required expensive,
>> external
>> resources (there were about 10) from tests than ran entirely in
>> memory
>> (there were about 400). The in-memory tests ran in about 6
>> seconds.
>
> I will add that on my last project we had 2000+ /unit/ tests that ran
> in
> 20 - 30 seconds. Our functional tests (over 30) at one point were
> running in 17 minutes. With 1.5 days of refactoring the functional
> tests they ran in 3 - 5 minutes.
>
> If you are keeping count that is 2030+ tests within 5 minutes, an
> average of 406 tests per minute (but let's not forget that the unit
> tests ran about 4000 - 6060 per minute). Those are not shabby numbers,
> but they aren't the best either. There was definite room for
> improvement, but we found that the ROI was not high enough to bring
> them
> down anymore.

That's wonderful. But it's impossible and likely incorrect to compare
those results to any other project in any way other than a purely
statistical analysis over many, many projects. There are far too many
other variables involved when running the tests.

Some people *have* encountered a lower limit to test execution time,
for whatever reasons, and so it's reasonable to look for ways to
(automatically or not) order the test execution based on recognized
dependencies.

And while it's true as JB notes that you might not be able to have a
theoretically 100% accurate dependency tracking, a 95% accurate reading
would probably be better than running tests too infrequently because
they take too long, or spending a lot of time manually munging about
reconfiguring test suites.
